div1.p: Carter comments on maps to be included in Section III of Henry Rose Carter's History of Yellow Fever.

div1.head: Memorandum from Laura Armistead Carter to Sylvanus Griswold Morley, November 30, 1926

November 30, 1926.
Memorandum
for
Dr. Morley
div1.p:
Map No 1: (a) As Mr. Weckerly suggests, we can leave out the extreme
southern part of south America--say from 40' South.? (cld be further north

(b) Map is all right for Africa, but should extend farther
westward for the Americas. Africa East? As drawn it does not take in Middle America:
Mexico nor the Southern part of the U. S.--this last not necessary, but
to balance the African Coast [unclear] on the northern part of our map.
Middle American and Mexican Coasts should certainly be included (poten-
tially infectable territory). I think then that this map should keep
its present northern boundary and extend as far west as does map No. 3--possibly
as far as map No. 2.

(c) Of course, I understand from Mr. Weckerly's letter that
the enclosed outlines are mere suggestions and assume that Map No. 1,
when completed will include all the principal islands, and groups of
islands, included between the portions of Africa and the Americas herein
portrayed--i. e. Madeira: Canaries: C. Verde: Bahamas: Antilles: Windward
Windward
-2-
and Leeward: Trinidad etc. etc. Some of these islands have an important
bearing on the entomological argument (in re relaying yellow fever).

Map. No. 2: (a) This map, in its present form, does not give the Carib
area, which you stipulated should be “specially marked.”

To quote from Father's History of Yellow Fever: (Page 101--original
MSS, of which you have carbon: P. 10 office copy):

“Believed to originally from the Amazon valley, the Caribs apparently had
begun their war upon, and displacement of, the Arrowacks and Lucayans no great
while before the discovery of America and were extending it when the Spaniards
came. They were bold navigators, going from the mainland up the chain of the
Little Antilles to Porto Rico: Higuey (the south side of Sto. Domingo) and
Cuba. When first seen by the whites they occupied much, but not all, of the
part of the Caribbean litoral of the mainland, “from the mouth of the Essiquibo
to the Gulf of Maracaibo” says Brinton (1891). “West of this they did not
reach the coast--spite of frequent assertions to the contrary.” They occu-
pied also practically all of the Little Antilles which were inhabited.
Some of them were not inhabited at all when first visited by the whites, and
a number not permanently. In Porto Rico and Hispaniola they occupied only
parts of the islands, more of the first than the last, having apparently
arrived only recently. ***************(Foot note)

(Foot note): The Sun Blas Indians, Brinton states, are not Caribs, but Cunas,
which family extended from the Gulf of Uraba to the Chagres” etc. (End f. N)

(b) I think then, that if we should move the eastern limit of map No. 2 to
coincide with that of Map No. 3 (keeping the other limits are drawn) it would
be about what we need, don't you?

Possibly this may contain more territory than you need for Plate 4-a (il-
lustrating conditions before the Conquest), but we shall certainly need all
that is included in our amended outline for the contrasting map (Plate 4-b)
after the Conquest; including the outlying islands mentioned above, and all
all
-3-
other important islands, or groups of islands, connected with the Conquest
and the explorations and settlements subsequent thereto.

Map No. 3: This map seems to contain everything we need for Section 111:
Part 1 Continued (expeditions of Ojeda: Nicuesa et al). Indeed it goes farther
west than is actually necessary, but I think we had better leave it as it
is, as, if it is an error, its an error in the right direction.

Of course, when we have moved the eastern line of Map No. 2 to coincide
with the eastern line of Map No. 3, it may be that we can use the second
plate of Map No. 2 (Plate 4-b: after the Conquest) to illustrate the ex-
peditions of Ojeda: Nicuesa etc. I had not expected, however, that Map No. 2
would be in sufficient detail for this (See MSS of Section 111: Part 1 and
Part 1 Continued sent you, December 2, 1926 from Baltimore). However, we can
take this up next Monday, December 6th., and the Carnegie.
